What are the benefits of using VerusIDs, and how do they provide security and control for users?

VerusIDs offer several benefits that provide security and control for users. Here are some of the key advantages:

**Quantum-ready Friendly Crypto-addresses:** VerusIDs can be used to receive and send funds, with complete control over the single or multi-sig addresses specified in the identity itself. If the controlling addresses or single/multi-sig properties are changed, all future spends of UTXOs sent to that identity will follow the updated spend conditions and be subject to the updated keys. This means that users have complete control over their funds and can update their identity as needed. Additionally, VerusIDs are resistant to quantum attacks with known algorithms, and the Verus ecosystem is working on integrating a quantum secure signature scheme. This will allow users to change their ID and make all funds sent to it retroactively quantum resistant.

**Fully Decentralized Protocol:** Anyone can create a VerusID and have complete, self-sovereign control over it without needing permission. All costs to create an ID go to miners, stakers, and ID referrers, ensuring that the ecosystem is decentralized and community-driven.

**Revocable:** Each VerusID includes a revocation authority, which defaults to the identity self. This means that the controller of the identity has the permission to revoke the identity, creating a valid transaction that, once mined into a block, prevents the identity from being used to spend or sign until it is recovered. This effectively freezes all of its funds, for example, in the case of key theft.

In summary, VerusIDs provide users with complete control over their funds, security against quantum attacks, and a fully decentralized protocol that allows for self-sovereign control. The revocable feature also provides an additional layer of protection against unauthorized access to funds.

### Quantum-ready friendly crypto-addresses on the worldwide Verus network
VerusIDs can be used to receive and send funds, which are controlled by the single or multi-sig addresses specified in the identity itself. If these controlling addresses or the single or multi-sig properties are changed, which can be done by the controller of the identity, all future spends of UTXOs sent to that identity follow the updated spend conditions and are subject to the updated keys. Although Verus 0.6.0 does not include quantum resistant signatures for transactions, VerusIDs are themselves resistant to quantum attack with known algorithms, and we have already started to integrate a quantum secure signature scheme, which we expect to activate on mainnet early next year. When that is available, it will be possible to change an ID and have all of the funds sent to it made retroactively quantum resistant.
